entry.title: Balance Carryforward - S/4 Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm currently facing an issue in the context of a support project on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition. The client has requested a custom field in the balance sheet to display consolidation adjustments by company code. However, during the balance carryforward process, the values in this custom field are not being transferred into the opening balance of the next fiscal year.

Do you know if this is standard behavior for custom fields in the Public Cloud Edition, or could it be related to a configuration setting?

Any insights or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Reading Messages from PI System
entry.content:
• version: The number of the message version to read. Use -1 to read the newest version, or a number larger/equal 0 to read older versions. E.g. if there are 4 message versions existing, valid values are 0, 1, 2 and -1. Please note that 3 isn‚Äôt a valid value in this example, since -1 has to be used to read the newest message version.

No matter the version I use, always donwloads the same payload, the latest one.

Anyone faced this issue? Is it a patch level issue?

entry.title: Fetch Request token or ID Token from OAuth Grant Code Authentication
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are doing integration with OpenText system via SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration. OpenText accepts only ID_Token to authenticate. We have an App which is registered in the Microsoft Azure and we generated the Client Credentials in the App. We use the microsoft login OAuth API initially to get the Access, Refresh and ID_Token and then use this ID_token to authenticate and call other OpenText API's. 

The solution is possible if I generate the refresh token in POSTMAN then use it in my Stored artifacts to generate another refresh token everytime. But I want to make this dynamic. 

I used the function getAccesTokenForOauth2AuthorizationCodeCredential to get the Access Token, but this does not return me the Refresh Token or ID_Token which is available along with the Access_Token. I tried to use the authentication using POSTMAN and the response JSON contains all these Tokens. Is there another way to get the all Tokens? Does SAP has another function with supports this? This is a critical factor for one of our integrations with OpenText which only accepts ID_Token containing the User Context.

entry.title: Debugging ‚Äúunsupported_grant_type‚Äù in SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration ‚Äî A Complete Walkthrough
entry.content:
Author: Ayush Aggarwal
*SAP Integration Developer | Building Reliable SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration Interfaces | Passionate about Real-World Problem Solving

üß† Introduction

If you‚Äôve ever integrated SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration with an on-prem OAuth token service, you‚Äôve probably seen this frustrating response at least once:

{"error": "unsupported_grant_type"}

It looks like a backend issue ‚Äî but in my case, the real problem was layered across Cloud Integration, Groovy, and the Cloud Connector.

Everything worked perfectly in Postman, yet consistently failed inside SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration.
Here‚Äôs how I diagnosed and resolved it ‚Äî step by step.

‚öôÔ∏èThe Scenario

My SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration iFlow needed to fetch an OAuth token from an on-premise endpoint (hosted on Microsoft IIS / ASP.NET) through the SAP Cloud Connector.

The expected request looked like this:

POST /token
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

grant_type=password&
username=API_USER&
password=MySecurePassword123!&
oauth_bearer_secret=AbCdEfGhIjKlMnOpQrStUvWxYz123456$CF)J@NcRf&
ip=192.168.0.10

In Postman, this returned a valid token instantly.
But from SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration, the response was always:

{"error": "unsupported_grant_type"}

üîçStep 1 ‚Äì Verifying Headers and Cloud Connector Path

The first thing I checked was the HTTP Request Headers in SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration trace (Before HTTP Adapter).
To my surprise, it only showed Cloud Connector‚Äìrelated headers:

SAP-Connectivity-ConsumerAccount
SAP-Connectivity-SCC-Location_ID
SAP-PASSPORT

No Content-Type, no Accept.
That meant the backend wasn‚Äôt even treating my payload as a form submission ‚Äî it was likely ignoring the body completely.

üß† Step 2 ‚Äì Encoding and Header Configuration

Next, I added a Groovy Script before the HTTP adapter to URL-encode all fields safely:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import java.net.URLEncoder

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def props = message.getProperties()
    def enc = { v -> URLEncoder.encode(v ?: "", "UTF-8") }

    def body = "grant_type=${enc(props.get('Grant_type'))}" +
               "&username=${enc(props.get('User'))}" +
               "&password=${enc(props.get('Password'))}" +
               "&oauth_bearer_secret=${enc(props.get('Secret'))}" +
               "&ip=${enc(props.get('IP'))}"

    message.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded")
    message.setHeader("Accept", "application/json")
    message.setBody(body)
    return message
}

Still no luck ‚Äî the same error persisted.

üïµÔ∏è Step 3 ‚Äì The ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù Moment: HTTP Method Was GET

After a few more trace analyses, I finally spotted the culprit:
My HTTP adapter was configured to use GET, because we were ‚Äújust fetching a token.‚Äù

But OAuth token endpoints must always use POST.

Why?
Because they only parse grant_type, username, and password from the body, not from the query string.

Changing the method to POST immediately changed the server‚Äôs behavior ‚Äî the request started reaching the backend handler correctly.

‚ö†Ô∏èStep 4 ‚Äì Another Twist: Groovy GString Conversion Error

Just when I thought it was fixed, SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration threw a new error:

org.apache.camel.InvalidPayloadException:
No type converter available to convert from type GStringImpl to InputStream

This happens because Groovy‚Äôs string interpolation ("${variable}") produces a GString, not a plain String ‚Äî
and the HTTP adapter can‚Äôt automatically convert it into an InputStream.

The fix?
Convert the body to a plain String explicitly before setting it:

message.setBody(body.toString())

That single .toString() solved the conversion issue once and for all.

üéâStep 5 ‚Äì Success!

After redeploying with:

  • HTTP Method: POST

  • Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

  • Body: body.toString()

‚Ä¶the flow finally returned a 200 OK and a valid token JSON üéØ

üßæ Summary of Root Causes

Layer Issue Fix

SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration ConfigurationMethod was set to GETChange to POST
Groovy ScriptBody was a GStringImplUse .toString()
Cloud ConnectorContent-Type wasn‚Äôt passed earlierRe-add header right before HTTP adapter

üß† Key Learnings for SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration Developers

‚úÖAlways use POST when requesting OAuth tokens ‚Äî GET requests won‚Äôt parse the body.
‚úÖConvert Groovy interpolated strings to Java strings using .toString().
‚úÖSet Content-Type explicitly as application/x-www-form-urlencoded.
‚úÖRead the trace logs carefully ‚Äî the ‚ÄúBefore HTTP Adapter‚Äù payload is your truth source.
‚úÖDon‚Äôt assume that Postman and SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration behave the same ‚Äî even identical payloads can differ in transport semantics.

üì∑Screenshots

  • SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration HTTP Receiver Adapter configuration

  • 404 Error

  • Successful token response in trace

üí¨Conclusion

This issue was a reminder that in integration, 99% of ‚Äúbackend errors‚Äù come from how we send the data, not the data itself.

After hours of debugging, the fix turned out to be:

  • One configuration change (POST instead of GET)

  • One line of code (body.toString())

Sometimes, the smallest details make the biggest difference.

 

üë§About the Author

Ayush Aggarwal is an SAP Integration Developer with expertise in SAP BTP IS Cloud Integration, Cloud Connector, and data integrations across SAP and cloud platforms.
He enjoys sharing practical, real-world lessons learned from deep debugging scenarios to help fellow developers save time and effort.

entry.title: SAP on IBM i Webcast: A new paradigm for <sid>ADM - not just for IBM i 7.6
entry.content:
<sid>ADM is the main user profile on IBM i to administer an SAP system at the operating system level. Sharing the password of <sid>ADM among multiple system administrators is sometimes done at customer sites but is not desired. Also, if you are running IBM i 7.6 and want to benefit from the enhanced security of multi-factor authentication (MFA) for <sid>ADM, limitations in remote file systems make it difficult. In the upcoming SAP on IBM i webcast, we will present a new SAP tool to allow SAP system administrators to sign on with their own user profiles - optionally in IBM i 7.6 with MFA - and then easily switch to <sid>ADM to perform administration tasks on their SAP systems.

The webcast is scheduled for November 18th, 2025, at 4 pm CET, 10 am EST, 8:30 pm IST. Please visit the website at   to register for the webcast. In reply, you will receive a calendar entry to your email address with all the information that you need to join the webcast.

As usual, questions are welcome during the session. Some general Q&A time is also reserved at the end of the webcast for general questions and for your suggestions about possible topics for future webcasts.

If you can‚Äôt make the live session, a replay will be made available for registrants.

We hope to see you there!

entry.title: FM RV_BILLING_PRINT_VIEW has not mapped billing categories B and C.
entry.content:
We have an requirement to fill  E1EDP02 qualifier [001] for rebate credit notes to support with purchase order number from ‚ÄòB1 and ‚ÄòB3‚Äô billing types whose billing categories are B and C.

On checking further we could see the Billing Categories are hardcoded inside the FM RV_BILLING_PRINT_VIEW, they are filling the purchase document number i.e., BSTKD for document categories ‚ÄòA‚Äô OR ‚ÄòP‚Äô OR ‚ÄòD‚Äô OR ‚ÄòL‚Äô OR ‚ÄòI‚Äô.

And there is no code mentioned for Billing Category category ‚ÄòB‚Äô and  ‚ÄòC‚Äô to fill the purchase document number.

Our query is why Billing category B and C is not hardcoded in above standard FM RV_BILLING_PRINT_VIEW.

We have requirement to fill Purchase order number for IDOC E1EDP02 qualifier [001] for rebate credit notes B1 and B3 billing types whose billing categories B and C are not hard coded in standard FM.

Help us to know the reason why it is not mapped and how can we fulfill business requirement.

entry.title: Re: Designing UI5 Apps as Business Solution for SAP Build Work Zone - Part 2
entry.content:
Hi @theodore_abitbol 

this is really strange as to me everything seems correct. At least the app-host exists and has the correct content which fits to the URL. The xs-app.json is ok. Also the platform knows about it and calculates the URL.

Also at runtime you should find another request being sent to the same app-host, which is working. The URL should look like this:
https://dev-tal-ks9oev3t.launchpad.cfapps.eu20.hana.ondemand.com/701acd48-8d90-47d3-9921-993e6601220b.cap-ui.fdcCache_701acd48_8d90_47d3_9921_993e6601220b/~6924a2b3-72d7-4bcf-aab7-93938be7cd4f~/argon.ui.app.appcockpitruptureracine/apps/sap.ui.demo.fiorielementsapp/ui5AppInfo.json
Could you confirm that this request succeds?

In order to find the root cause we can try some things:
Is the destination SupplyControlTower_html_repo_host for the same app-host? It should not cause conflicts, but you could try to remove it.
Check the HTML5 Applications page on your sub account in the Cloud Cockpit. Is the app listed there? Open the network trace. It should do periodic calls to "getHTML5Applications" to get the list. Search for your app and extract the details especially the URLs.

Best regards
Matthias

entry.title: Re: Budget entity in compensation
entry.content:
Based on your screenshots, your budget is setup to be a % of salary (mode = PercentOfCurSal) and then your Component selected of Pago Adjustado is what spends money from that budget.

From what you are describing, you should be using a budget mode of PercentOfCustom field and then in the advanced options you would set the field the budget should be based on to be your budget base custom field.

Thanks,

Lesley

entry.title: SAP Ariba Procure to Order 2511 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Community, We're thrilled to share great new innovations in our upcoming release, 2511 with a strong focus on improved management of service requisitioning and overall UX improvements in Guided Buying. We are also pleased to share expanded capability in SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile app and improved user experience for catalog administrators, we hope you enjoy the highlights.

Support for Hierarchical Service Items in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-300)

Complex service procurements (for example, a laptop repair plus software maintenance and a parts kit) traditionally generate multiple requisitions, follow‚Äëups and approval cycles.

Service hierarchies let your teams create a single, coherent requisition that models the real delivery structure of work and items. That reduces administrative overhead, shortens cycle time to order, and gives finance and procurement better visibility into bundled spend ‚Äî all of which translate to faster time-to-value and lower operational cost.

Child items can include catalog and non-catalog services or goods. For example, you can create a non-catalog request for laptop repair service (parent service) and then add software maintenance service (child item) and computer cleaning kit (child item).

Service hierarchies help to define how services are structured and delivered, improving efficiency when ordering services.

You can use service hierarchies in the following scenarios:

  • When you create a service requisition using a non-catalog request or a line item form, you can add child items using the Add Child Item button.
  • On the checkout page, you can add child items to the request before you submit it.
  • If you submit a service requistion, you can withdraw it after it's submitted or partially approved, add child items, and then resubmit it.

When you create a non-catalog request for a service, the Add Child Item button, Expected Amount, and Max Amount display on the form, as shown in the following figure:

 The following figure displays a hierarchical service request:

 

This feature can be enabled through the following parameter:

PARAM_ENABLE_NON_CATALOG_SERVICE_HIERARCHY which enables service hierarchies for non-catalog requests and line item forms.

 

Hide Interim Supplier RFQ Bids (GUIDEB-1262)

You can now configure Guided Buying to hide interim supplier RFQ bids from users and display only awarded bids.

By default, guided buying displays all bids to users. However, taking onboard your feedback, some customers may prefer to hide interim bids and display only the winning bid after it has been awarded.

This capability is available only in high-touch RFQ scenarios, where professional buyers evaluate and award bids in SAP Ariba Sourcing.

If you enable this feature there will be some subtle changes to the UI in the following screens:

  • Receive quotes
  • Awarding
  • Confirm award
  • Bid overview section
  • Compare bids (both graph and table view)

You can enable this capability by setting a new guided buying parameter PARAM_ENABLE_HIDE_BIDS_IN_HIGH_TOUCH to true.

For more information about configuring API communication, see Guided Buying Parameters for RFQs

 

Display Requisition Amount in Approver's or Watcher's Currency (PROC-1029)

Given the global nature of business these days it's quite likely approvers may be overseas, to simplify this experience for an approver we have introduced the ability to display requisition amount upon approval in the approver (or watchers) preferred/default currency.

New fields such as Total in Your Currency at the header level and Amount in Your Currency at the line level are displayed for a requisition when the requisition is sent for approval:

 Your administrator can enable the through the following parameter: PARAM_ENABLE_APPROVERS_AMOUNT_IN_LOCAL_CURRENCY

 

Support for Budget Check in External ERP System for SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile App Requisitions (BMAA-479)

Its always important to know if your cost centre has sufficient budget to allow your requisition and corresponding PO to be created. We have now expanded requisition budget check capability to the SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile app too.

In the SAP Ariba Procurement mobile app, real-time budget check is performed in the external ERP system (normally the source to check the budget against the requisition) when users submit or withdraw requisitions, and also when requisitions are approved or denied.

To enable this capability your administrator can enable the parameter: Application.Mobile.EnableRTBCInExternalERPSystem

 

Enhancements to Catalog Replication Page (CMS-1418)

With this feature, the Catalog Replication page contains a new tab called Content that allows catalog administrators to search for catalogs quickly. The new design optimizes browsing and viewing large volumes of data.

Previously, the Catalog Replication page loaded all the catalogs in the Overview and Configuration tabs, which made it difficult for users to search for catalogs.

A new tab called Content is now displayed on the Catalog Replication page. As a catalog administrator, you can search for a catalog by its name and type (subscribed or unsubscribed). By default, the number of catalogs displayed on the page is limited to 1000.

We are happy today to have covered an important set of features to benefit end users, approvers and also catalog administrators with the aim to streamline work by presenting the right information front and centre to get the job done quickly and efficiently throughout the buying process.

For further useful information:

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2511 release- Multi-registration link and for CIM customers- P2P link  (Thanks Natalie!)
  • Resources:
    • Feature related materials
      • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
      • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
    • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
    • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
    • What‚Äôs New

entry.title: Re: Manage My Team Tile Error: "An application error occurred"
entry.content:

entry.title: Re: What is correct set up of Rebate sales condition type...
entry.content:
Hi @Narendar_Bureddy, 

Regarding the presence of RES1 in pricing procedure RVAA01, I would recommend reviewing the change log for that procedure in your system. In standard SAP (at least as of S/4HANA OP 2023), RES1 is not part of the standard RVAA01 pricing procedure, and I suspect it may have been added through a customization.

Recommendation Setup:

  • In the customer billing pricing procedure (RVAA01), you should maintain the accrual condition type REA1. This allows the system to post accruals at the time of sales invoice creation, which is the expected behavior for standard sales rebate processing.

  • In the Condition Contract (via WCOCO), you should maintain both REA1 and RES1:

    • REA1 for accruals at the time of source document creation + also considered at the time of Delta accrual.

    • RES1 for settlement during partial/final/delta processing.

There are alternative approaches where only RES1 is maintained in the contract and accruals are still calculated, but this typically requires additional configuration or custom logic. SAP‚Äôs best practice still recommends using both REA1 and RES1 for full control and transparency.

Also, when inserting REA1 into RVAA01, make sure it comes after step 400 (Pricing total for Rebate Basis), unless you have specific requirements (e.g., to include/exclude freight or surcharges in your base for accrual calculation). The positioning will depend on how you define your rebate base.

Regards, 
Gauthier VICTOR

entry.title: Smarter Built-In Support in C4C: A Unified and Upgraded Experience
entry.content:
Built-In Support Upgrade Coming with Release 2511

With the upcoming 2511 release, SAP Sales & Service Cloud (V1) receives a major upgrade to its built-in support experience.
Customers will continue to report issues directly from within their tenant , now through the next-generation Built-In Support, seamlessly integrated with SAP for Me.

 This is the same modern Built-In Support already available in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 and other SAP Cloud solutions , bringing V1 fully in line with SAP‚Äôs unified support model.

 Flexibility by Design

Customers now have complete flexibility:

  • create and manage SAP support cases directly from their tenant using Built-In Support 

  • work entirely from SAP for Me,

  • or switch freely between both , all cases are fully synchronized and managed centrally.

 

* only key user can access built in support and forward cases to SAP.

 The Best of Both Worlds

This evolution brings the best of both worlds:
‚úÖ the in-application convenience customers already know,
‚úÖ combined with the powerful tools and insights available in SAP for Me , including real-time support channels, intelligent search, guided assistance, and complete case management.

The result: a smarter, faster, and more unified support experience across SAP‚Äôs ecosystem.

What‚Äôs New in Built-In Support

The new Built-In Support delivers choice, speed, and intelligence:

  • Real-time support options: Expert Chat, Schedule an Expert, Ask an Expert Peer

  • AI-powered search and guided support assistant for quicker solutions

  • Rich text editing and larger attachments for clearer communication

  • Enhanced case logging with guided steps to select the right priority and document business impact

  • Instant synchronization with SAP for Me (no more 15-minute delays)

  • Accurate case ownership , the creator is correctly identified in SAP for Me 

  • Unified access across all SAP cloud solutions

  • Enhanced reporting and dashboards in SAP for Me, Cloud availability insights, Central case management, Cloud availability insights, Trust Center, etc

This upgrade also aligns C4C V1 with the same built-in support experience already available in V2, ensuring a consistent and future-ready support model across the SAP portfolio..

Learn more:
‚û°Ô∏è Getting Support Using Built in Support 

We recommend to consider completed the support accreditation which also covers the features and benefits of Built in Support

What Stays the Same

We‚Äôre not changing your familiar workflow , Key Users can still create and track their own cases directly in your C4C tenant.
Built-In Support remains embedded, now simply smarter, faster, and seamlessly connected to SAP for Me.

End user management remains accessible with he old tool but is limited to internal support only.

 

 Why This Upgrade Matters

The original Built-In Support in C4C V1 was based on legacy technology that limited access to newer SAP innovations.

With the upgraded Built-In Support and SAP for Me integration, customers now benefit from:

  • A modern, AI-enabled experience

  • Real-time engagement with SAP experts

  • Centralized visibility across products

  • Smarter case handling and improved CES outcomes

This is not a change in workflow,  it‚Äôs an upgrade to a faster, smarter, and more flexible support experience.

 What to Expect Next

  • The upgrade is planned  with the 2511 release.

  • Existing open cases from the legacy built-in support will become editable in SAP for Me.

    SAP Knowledge Base Article  3665054 - How to Find and Process, in SAP for Me, Cases created from a ByD or C4C tenant

  • We recommend verifying that all relevant users have valid S-user IDs and access to SAP for Me. Built in support requires to sign in with a valid S user  to access case management and case creation

 

 

Summary

The new Built-In Support in SAP Sales & Service Cloud (V1) is a smarter, faster, and more flexible way to connect with SAP Support.

You can now:
‚úÖ Create cases from your tenant (via Built-In Support)
‚úÖ Manage them in SAP for Me
‚úÖ Access real-time support channels
‚úÖ Benefit from AI guidance and enhanced reporting

All fully synchronized ‚Äî giving you one unified experience powered by Built-In Support and SAP for Me.
This is the future of SAP Support.

üìö Further Reading

Relevant Links

  • SAP Support Portal Landing Page‚Äã
  • Built-In Support Documentation ‚Äã
  • SAP News Center Article‚Äã
  • SAP Knowledge Base Article 3000949 - How to create a support case in Built-In Support
  • SAP Knowledge Base Article 3584368 - How to log in to Built-In Support and activate support functions
  • SAP Knowledge Base Article  3665054 - How to Find and Process, in SAP for Me, Cases created from a ByD or C4C tenant

  • Known Limitations of Built-In Support

entry.title: Frontend Strategies for SAP Sales Cloud V2: An Architect‚Äôs Perspective on Modern UI Extensions
entry.content:
Introduction

As an SAP architect, I‚Äôm sharing my perspective on choosing the right frontend technologies and design strategies for SAP Sales Cloud V2. Selecting the appropriate frontend is not just about framework preference‚Äîit impacts user experience, integration, maintainability, performance, scalability, and adherence to SAP‚Äôs design principles.

While SAP Fiori provides a standardized and proven design framework, Sales Cloud V2 introduces a modern, non-Fiori-based UI. In this article, I‚Äôll provide guidance on balancing Fiori compliance, lightweight frontend frameworks like React, seamless backend integration, performance, and scalability, along with best practices for extensions, mashups, and side-by-side scenarios with S/4HANA.

Understanding SAP Sales Cloud V2's UI

SAP Sales Cloud V2 introduces a modern, intuitive UI designed to enhance user experience and productivity. Unlike traditional SAP Fiori applications, V2's UI is not strictly Fiori-based. It leverages contemporary design principles to provide a seamless and engaging user interface.

For a visual overview of SAP Sales Cloud V2 UI.

 

Frontend Development Considerations

1. Aligning with SAP Fiori Design Principles

SAP Fiori offers a set of design principles aimed at creating consistent and user-friendly interfaces. While V2's UI is not Fiori-based, developers can still adhere to Fiori's design guidelines to ensure a cohesive user experience. Key considerations include:

  • Consistency: Maintaining uniform design elements across applications.
  • Efficiency: Optimizing workflows to reduce user effort.
  • Intuitiveness: Designing interfaces that are easy to understand and navigate.
  • Performance: Ensuring fast rendering and responsiveness.
  • Scalability: Designing the frontend to handle growing user loads and data volumes efficiently.

2. Choosing the Right Frontend Technology

The choice of frontend technology should align with the application's requirements and the desired user experience. Consider:

  • Fiori Elements : Ideal for OData-based applications requiring standardized UI patterns. Leveraging SAP BTP CAP best practices, Fiori Elements provide:
    • Metadata-driven UI generation (List Report, Object Page, Analytical List Page)
    • Out-of-the-box CRUD operations
    • Automatic audit and change history tracking
    • Attachment management support
    • Extensibility for custom fields and actions
    • Rapid development and lower TCO
    • Consistency with SAP Fiori design guidelines
    • Built-in navigation, filtering, and sorting features
    • Seamless integration with CAP services and OData endpoints
  • UI5 Web Components for React: Use Fiori-compliant components within a React app to combine flexibility with consistency.
    Documentation
  • React with Custom Components: For applications requiring highly customized UI aligned with Sales Cloud V2 look & feel.
  • UI5 Freestyle (SAPUI5): For deep integration with SAP backend and traditional Fiori look & feel.

When to Choose Fiori Elements for Sales Cloud V2

  • Backend services are OData-based
  • Standard UI patterns like List Report, Object Page, or Analytical List Page meet requirements
  • Minimal custom UI is needed
  • Out-of-the-box features (CRUD, attachments, audit/change history) are beneficial
  • Strict adherence to Fiori design guidelines is required
  • Faster delivery and lower TCO is a priority
  • Extensibility for custom fields and actions is needed

Balancing Look & Feel vs Out-of-the-Box Fiori

When integrating with backend services, consider:

  • Use Fiori Elements: When OData backend, standard UI patterns suffice, and business prioritizes rapid delivery, TCO, and built-in CAP features.
  • Use Custom / Lightweight Frontend: When business requires UI to match Sales Cloud V2 look & feel, heavy customization, or mashups.
  • Hybrid Approach: Combine CAP Fiori Elements for standard functionality with custom/lightweight frontends for specialized UI requirements.

Backend Integration Considerations

  • OData Services: Standard SAP protocol for frontend-backend communication
  • GraphQL: Flexible alternative to OData
  • REST APIs: For external service integration

Choose the backend service type that aligns with your frontend framework to ensure seamless integration, optimal performance, and scalability.

Extensions, Mashups, and SAP Build Apps

SAP Sales Cloud V2 supports extensions and mashups to enhance functionality:

  • Sales Cloud Extensions: Built on SAP BTP to extend V2 capabilities
  • Mashups: Embed external apps or services into Sales Cloud interface

Mashup-Based HTML UI

  • Work List: Mashup as work center feature
  • Detail View: Display detailed info in context
  • Quick View: Summarized data for fast access

Extensibility Using SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps enables no-code/low-code apps for all form factors. Extensions can be embedded in Sales Cloud V2.

  • Included for tenants with 100+ users
  • Additional licensing required for fewer than 100 users

References for Mashups and SAP Build Apps

  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Solution Guide (PDF)
  • SAP Build Apps Setup Guide for Sales Cloud V2
  • Design and Develop Extensions using SAP AppGyver

Recommendations

  • Use Fiori Elements (CAP/UI5) for OData-based apps with standard UI patterns and built-in features (CRUD, attachments, audit)
  • Use React / custom frontend to match Sales Cloud V2 look & feel when business requires visual consistency or heavy customization
  • Use UI5 Freestyle for deep SAP backend integration and traditional Fiori UX
  • Consider hybrid approaches combining Fiori Elements and custom/lightweight frontends
  • Extensions and mashups should prioritize performance, consistency, security
  • Side-by-side scenarios with S/4HANA: maintain SAP UI5 for OData backend integration
  • Backend service type (OData, REST, GraphQL) influences frontend choice and integration approach

References

  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Overview
  • UI5 Web Components for React Documentation
  • Comparison Between SAPUI5 and Web Components
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 Features and Roadmap
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 with S/4HANA in Action
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 Solution Guide (PDF)
  • SAP Build Apps Setup Guide for Sales Cloud V2
  • Design and Develop Extensions using SAP AppGyver

Key Takeaways

  • Choosing the frontend technology for SAP Sales Cloud V2 requires balancing look & feel, performance, scalability, and integration capabilities.
  • For Fiori-compliant UI, Fiori Elements (CAP/UI5) or UI5 Freestyle are preferred for OData-based apps.
  • For customized, lightweight UI aligned with Sales Cloud V2, use React or other modern frameworks.
  • CAP Fiori Elements provide out-of-the-box advantages: CRUD, attachments, audit/change history, navigation, filtering, and extensibility.
  • Hybrid approaches can combine standard Fiori Elements with custom frontends for specialized UX needs.
  • Backend service type (OData, REST, GraphQL) influences frontend technology choice.
  • Extensions and mashups should prioritize consistency, performance, and security.
  • Side-by-side scenarios (Sales Cloud V2 & S/4HANA) benefit from using SAP UI5 technologies for OData backend integration.

entry.title: Re: Service Contract number missing in billing document (...
entry.content:
Good day @DavidBirrer 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Solution Orders, Output Management

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for Sales Billing, Maintain Form Templates

In summary, in public cloud edition, the billing document inherits the Solution Order reference by standard, but the Service Contract number is not automatically passed to the invoice output or XML payload. This has become a common requirement in public cloud, especially when Solutions Orders generate Service Contracts that are later billed together with other items. (e.g., subscriptions for service orders).

My advice is to extend your invoice form, or you use BAdI SD_BIL_OUTPUT_DATA_MODIFY to expose the Service Contract number in the XML output. You don‚Äôt require any configuration in Solution Order or billing control beyond this.

Below is a clean-core step-by-step options to Expose the Service Contract Number:

Search ‚ÄúMaintain Form Templates‚Äù

The example below references a different custom version. In your form SD_BIL_INV should be copied to a custom version.

Ensure you add Service Contract Number and map it from the billing item data. In the Data Source, include Reference Document or Service Contract Number. √† Then Bind this field to the XML output context or PDF layout where needed. √† Then activate and assign the new form in Output Parameter Determination.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Reimagining Supplier Booking in Service Cloud V2 Service Orders
entry.content:
In service operations, every minute counts. When a customer‚Äôs equipment breaks down, the speed at which parts or services can be procured often decides the overall service experience. Traditionally, finding and booking a supplier is a time-consuming, manual process ‚Äî switching across systems, endless searches, and delayed approvals.

With SAP Service Cloud V2, we‚Äôve turned this challenge into an opportunity:
üëâEnabling service agents to search, select, and book suppliers directly from the service order screen ‚Äî backed by real-time integration, AI recommendations, and automated purchase requisition creation in S/4HANA.

Why This Matters

  • Faster service delivery ‚Äì Agents don‚Äôt waste time on manual supplier lookups.
  • Smarter decisions ‚Äì AI recommends the best supplier based on availability, cost, and past performance.
  • Seamless integration ‚Äì Purchase requisitions are automatically created in S/4HANA, ensuring compliance.
  • Better customer experience ‚Äì Faster parts procurement = quicker issue resolution.

How It Works

When customers raise a Case followed by creation of service order by an agent  , speed and accuracy are everything. Delays in finding the right supplier or creating purchase requisitions can slow down resolution and impact customer satisfaction.

üîπStep 1: Supplier Search in Service Order

Agents open a Service Order in Service Cloud V2 and access a supplier search panel built with SAP Build Apps.

SAP Build APPs:

 

 

 

 

This the destination where we call SAP S4HANA Suppliers using SAP CAPM

 

üîπStep 2: Fetch Supplier Data from S/4HANA

The system makes an API call to S/4HANA to fetch available suppliers with details such as pricing, lead time, and rating.

üîπStep 3: AI Recommendation with RAG

We use Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to analyze supplier data and recommend the most suitable supplier for the request.

üîπStep 4: Supplier Selection & Purchase Requisition

Once the supplier is confirmed, a Purchase Requisition is instantly created in S/4HANA via API ‚Äî no manual intervention needed.

üîπStep 5: Persistence & Metadata with CAP

All supplier interactions, recommendations, and decision logs are stored via SAP CAP, ensuring traceability and audit readiness.

 

 

Solution Architecture

  • SAP Service Cloud V2 ‚Äì Service order management
  • SAP Build Apps ‚Äì UI for supplier search & booking
  • S/4HANA APIs ‚Äì Fetch suppliers + post purchase requisition
  • AI with RAG ‚Äì Intelligent supplier recommendations
  • SAP CAP ‚Äì Database layer for persistence & metadata

 

 

End-to-End Flow

  1. Agent opens service order in Service Cloud V2.
  2. Supplier search triggered via Build Apps UI.
  3. Supplier data fetched from S/4HANA APIs.
  4. RAG model recommends best supplier.
  5. Agent confirms ‚Üí Purchase Requisition created in S/4HANA.
  6. Metadata stored in CAP for reporting and audit.

Business Impact

‚úîÔ∏è80% reduction in supplier booking effort
‚úîÔ∏èImproved procurement compliance with auto-PR creation
‚úîÔ∏èAI-driven supplier choice ‚Üí faster and smarter decisions
‚úîÔ∏èUnified service experience ‚Äì all from within Service Cloud V2

Closing Thoughts

This solution is a perfect example of how SAP‚Äôs ecosystem (Service Cloud V2, Build Apps, S/4HANA, CAP, and AI) can work together to simplify complex business processes.

By embedding supplier booking directly into the service order workflow, we‚Äôve not only accelerated service execution but also paved the way for intelligent, AI-powered procurement in the future.

entry.title: AI-Powered Self-Service API in SAP ITSM Adapter: Transforming SAP Support
entry.content:
Introduction

In today‚Äôs digital-first business landscape, organizations expect fast, accurate, and autonomous support. SAP has introduced an innovative capability that addresses this expectation ‚Äî the AI-powered Self-Service API within the SAP Cloud ALM ITSM Adapter.

This new functionality enables AI-driven, automated assistance that provides customers with immediate solutions through SAP Notes, Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs), and other SAP documentation, often resolving issues before a support ticket is even created.

What Is the SAP ITSM Adapter API?

The SAP Cloud ALM ITSM Adapter API serves as an integration bridge between SAP Cloud ALM and external IT Service Management (ITSM) systems such as ServiceNow,.

It provides REST-based interfaces that allow organizations to:

    • Create and manage SAP support cases directly from their ITSM systems.

    • Synchronize  master data (s-users/landscape information data) between customer ITSM and SAP Support Backbone

    • Connect seamlessly to the SAP Support Backbone for consistent case handling and tracking.

This integration ensures that SAP and customer support teams operate within a unified process and shared visibility.

What‚Äôs New: AI-Driven Self-Service API

The Self-Service API enhances this integration by embedding Artificial Intelligence (AI) directly into the SAP support flow.

Instead of always creating a new SAP case, the system now uses AI and natural language processing to analyze issue details and propose immediate recommendations ‚Äî powered by SAP‚Äôs extensive support knowledge base.

Key Features

  • AI-Powered Analysis
    The API interprets user inputs such as issue descriptions, system IDs, and error codes to understand the context.
  • Automated Knowledge Recommendations
    The AI engine searches SAP‚Äôs knowledge repositories and suggests SAP Notes, KBAs, or support documentation relevant to the problem.
  • Instant Self-Service Resolution
    Users can review recommendations and apply fixes immediately ‚Äî often resolving the issue without needing SAP engineer intervention.
  • Continuous Learning
    The system continuously learns from resolved cases to refine and improve future recommendations.
  • Seamless Integration
    The API can be embedded into customer-facing portals, chatbots, or ITSM UIs, creating a unified and intelligent self-service experience.

Business Benefits

  • Faster Issue Resolution
    Customers receive instant, AI-generated recommendations ‚Äî reducing downtime and eliminating unnecessary ticket creation.
  • Reduced Support Overhead
    By resolving repetitive or known issues automatically, the API helps reduce manual workload for IT teams.
  • Improved End-User Experience
    Users get 24/7 self-service support, faster responses, and higher satisfaction.
  • Data-Driven Insights
    Organizations gain visibility into common issue types, self-service success rates, and potential knowledge base improvements.

 

Example Workflow: AI-Driven SAP Case Creation with Self-Service

The following diagram illustrates how the AI-powered Self-Service API integrates with a customer‚Äôs ITSM system to streamline SAP case creation.

Figure 1: ITSM Integration ‚Äì SAP Case Creation with Self-Service (API-based)

Step-by-Step Process

Internal Ticket Created
A user raises a support ticket in the customer‚Äôs ITSM system (e.g., ServiceNow or Jira).

  1. SAP Case Candidate Generated
    The system determines SAP support may be required and creates a SAP Case Candidate with relevant details such as subject, system, component, and S-User contact.
  2. Send Case Candidate to SAP Cloud ALM
    The ITSM system sends a partial or full payload through the SAP ITSM Adapter API.
  3. AI Generates Self-Service Content
    SAP Cloud ALM uses AI Support Services to analyze the ticket data and produce self-service content, including:
    - SAP Note or KBA recommendations
    - Component suggestions
    - Other contextual solutions
  4. Customer Reviews Self-Service Recommendations
    The recommendations are displayed within the ITSM interface.
    - If helpful, the user applies the solution and the issue is resolved automatically.
    - If not, the system proceeds to create a full SAP support case.
  5. SAP Case Creation (Full Payload)
    The ITSM system sends the complete case data to SAP Cloud ALM, which then creates a formal SAP case in the SAP Support Backbone.
  6. Case Resolution and Synchronization
    All updates and resolutions are synchronized between the customer ITSM and SAP, ensuring transparency and consistent status tracking.

AI-Driven Self-Service API, in action

Request Example

Here‚Äôs an example of how to use the SAP ITSM Adapter API endpoint /supportcases/recommendations/solutions in a self-service scenario to retrieve recommended solutions (e.g., SAP Notes or KBAs) based on a case description.

Endpoint

POST /supportcases/recommendations/solutions

This endpoint analyzes the problem description and returns the 10 most relevant solution documents. this result can be filtered by:

  • type, 
  • component
  • product
  • category
  • age

Request Body

{
  "description": "Security Code Scan on Results - vulnerability [CRLF injection/HTTP response splitting(Web Server)-Portal]"
}

Additional parameters may be provided to increase the accuracy of the result

Request answer

{

"count": 10,
"totalCount": 10,
"results": [
{

"id": "1475602",
"title": "Identifying and resolving security vulnerabilities in SAP Business Objects products [How-To]",
"summary": "A third-party tool such as WebInspect or AppScan has been pointed at a deployment of a SAP Business Objects product (BI 4.x/20xx- 4.1, 4.2 , 4.3, 2025 ) and the resulting report shows a number of security vulnerabilities (such as Cross Site Scripting",
"type": "KBA",
"component": "BI-BIP-SEC",
"product": "",
"category": "How To",
"recommended": false,
"age": "Released 4 months ago",
"url": "https://me.sap.com/notes/1475602",
"rank": 1

},.................

}

Implementation Tips

  • Integrate the Self-Service API into your existing ITSM interface or self-service portal for a unified user experience.
  • Use conversational AI or chatbots to collect issue descriptions and trigger the API.
  • Continuously update and validate your SAP Notes and KBA usage to maximize resolution accuracy.
  • Monitor key performance indicators (KPIs) such as self-service success rate, case deflection rate, and average time to resolution.
  • Ensure secure authentication (OAuth/SAML) and proper data governance across your IT landscape.

Looking Ahead

The introduction of the Self-Service API marks a step toward proactive, AI-driven support in SAP environments.

Future enhancements may include:

  • Conversational AI integration for natural language support.
  • Generative AI summarization of complex SAP Notes and KBAs.

Conclusion

The AI-powered Self-Service API within the SAP ITSM Adapter brings intelligence, speed, and automation to SAP support.

By leveraging AI insights, SAP Notes, and KBAs, customers can resolve many issues independently ‚Äî improving efficiency, reducing downtime, and optimizing the overall support experience.

This innovation not only enhances integration between customer ITSM systems and SAP Cloud ALM but also paves the way for a smarter, more proactive support model for SAP customers worldwide.

Learn More

SAP Cloud ALM ‚Äì ITSM Adapter API Overview (api.sap.com)

SAP Cloud ALM APIs Documentation (help.sap.com)

SAP Community: SAP Cloud ALM and ITSM Integration Blogs

entry.title: Overview of Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Posting Rules can be used for processing bank statement items. A posting rule determines exactly how a bank statement item is posted. It determines which accounts are posted to on debit and credit sides, and also whether or not the respective debit or credit side is cleared. Amongst other things, a posting rule can consist of a posting area, a debit/credit account symbol, a posting type and an on-account posting key.

They tell the system which G/L accounts to debit and credit, depending on the transaction type.

For example:
When a customer payment is received ‚Üí Debit the Bank Account, Credit the Customer Account.
When bank charges are posted ‚Üí Debit Bank Charges Expense, Credit Bank Account.

These rules ensure that every business transaction results in correct and consistent accounting entries without manual intervention.

Where Posting Rules Are Used

Posting rules are mainly used in:

  • Bank Account Management / Cash Management(Apps like Manage Bank Statement Rules, Manage Automatic Payments, Manage Posting Rules, etc.)
  • Payment Processing
    (e.g., in scope items like J58 ‚Äì Bank Account Management )
  • Incoming and Outgoing Bank Statement Processing
    (via Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items apps)

How Posting Rules Work

Each posting rule defines:

  • Posting Area (e.g., subledger, G/L)
  • Debit/Credit Indicators
  • G/L Accounts to be used
  • Posting Keys
  • Document Type

For example:
When you process an incoming bank statement, a posting rule determines:

  • Which account should be debited (e.g., Bank Clearing Account)
  • Which account should be credited (e.g., Customer Receivables)

To understand what exactly a particular posting rule does (which accounts are posted and cleared), have a look at the table under Overview of the Posting Rules.

Viewing or Modifying Posting Rules

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, configuration is managed via SAP-delivered content.
Therefore Posting rules are usually predefined by SAP and cannot be modified.

Examples of relevant SSCUIs (depending on your scope items and country version):

  • 102386 ‚Äì Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
  • 102387 ‚Äì Assign Accounts to Posting Rules

How to View or Configure Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Unlike the on-premise system, where you use transaction codes (like OT83, OT74, etc.),
in the Public Cloud version, posting rules are managed via configuration activities (SSCUI) in the Manage Your Solution or CBC (Central Business Configuration) tool.

Step-by-Step: Viewing Posting Rules

Step 1: Access Configuration

  1. Go to the SAP Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Open the app Manage Your Solution (or Configure Your Solution in new systems).
  3. Choose Configure Your Solution tile.

Step 2: Find the SSCUI for Posting Rules

  1. In the search bar, enter:
    "Bank Statement" or "Posting Rules"
  2. Look for the following configuration activities (SSCUI IDs may vary slightly by country):
    102386 ‚Äì Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
    102387 ‚Äì Assign Accounts to Posting Rules
    102385 ‚Äì Define Posting Keys and Posting Types

Step 3: Open the Configuration Step

  1. Click Open Activity.
  2. In Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements (102386), you can view all pre-delivered posting rules.
  3. Each posting rule shows posting area, posting type, debit/credit indicator, and document type.
  4. These rules are SAP-delivered and cannot be changed directly in Public Cloud to maintain integrity.

Step 4: Assign G/L Accounts

  1. Open Assign Accounts to Posting Rules (102387).
  2. Here you can see which G/L accounts are assigned to each posting rule and account symbol.
  3. You may adapt account assignments if your scope item allows (depending on business role and configuration permission).

Step 5: Test the Posting Rule

  1. Go to the app Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items.
  2. Upload or simulate a bank statement.
  3. The system automatically applies the posting rule based on the external transaction code or mapping configuration.
  4. You can then check the accounting document to verify which accounts were posted (via Display Journal Entries).

Modifying Posting Rules (Limitations in Public Cloud)

In Public Cloud, you cannot create or freely modify posting rules as in On-Premise or Private Cloud due to SAP‚Äôs standardization policy.

You can:

  • View and extend posting rules using SSCUI.
  • Assign or change G/L accounts linked to existing posting rules.
  • Create additional bank statement rules (via Manage Bank Statement Rules app) that determine which posting rule applies under certain conditions.

You cannot:

  • Add new posting areas.
  • Define entirely new posting rules or posting types beyond what SAP delivers.

Relevant Scope Items (Pre-Delivered Configurations)

Scope Item Description
J58Bank Account Management
J77Automatic Payments
J78Cash Operations
BD9

Bank Statement Processing

These scope items collectively handle posting rule configuration and bank integration.

entry.title: Re: ECC delivery qty not reduced when applying process co...
entry.content:
Note 2332231 - EWM split deliveries with zero quantity not updated in the ERP original delivery

Basically the system only updates the ECC delivery quantities after all the items in the EWM delivery is completed, meaning the ODO should be in the Completed status. Partially reduce the quantity to 0 is not possible without custom BADI logic.

entry.title: Re: Table KNVI ( Customer Master Tax Indicator ) generati...
entry.content:
One check you can do is go to CDHDR / CDPOS tables and see which user id showing for the extra entries in table KNVI. Some systems have background jobs (e.g., Customer Master Data Enhancer, Address Completer) that automatically enrich or supplement customer data after replication. These may create KNVI entries for missing combinations (e.g., sales org/distribution channel/division) based on default logic.

If you're using SAP MDG, DRF, or PI/PO, check if there are post-processing steps or enhancements in the replication framework that manipulate KNVI after initial sync.

entry.title: Reducing the DataBase Size of SAP ERP Systems Using Shell Copy Scenario
entry.content:
If your SAP ERP system has been running for an extended period, your database has probably grown several terabytes in size. This presents a double challenge: managing such a large volume of data is complex, and transitioning to SAP S/4HANA can lead to significant downtime. 

To unlock the digital transformation capabilities of the SAP Business Transformation Center (for more information, see [Everything about using SAP Business Transformation center for SDT S/4 HANA Conversion 2023 from ECC]), your target system needs to be manually prepared, as explained in [Creating the Shell System for SAP Business Transformation Center: A Practical Approach].  

If these challenges sound familiar, you‚Äôre in the right place! 

With Support Package 45 (SP45) of Software Provisioning Manager 1.0, a new scenario called "Shell Copy‚Äù is now available. Similar to the traditional ‚ÄúSystem Copy‚Äù process - where you use Software Provisioning Manager to copy or migrate an existing SAP ABAP system, the Shell Copy assists in system copying, but with one key difference: it significantly reduces the volume of your new target database. 

The Shell Copy scenario keeps the skeleton of your system, along with all your custom configurations and developments, such as cross-client customizing, dictionary, and repository data, while leaving out the application data (see item 1 in the diagram below). 

If needed, after performing a shell copy, you can use remote client copy (using the SAP_UCSV profile) for all clients except 000 (see item 2 in the diagram below).   A remote client copy for client 000 is not required as this is delivered during the Shell Copy process.

 

 

 

In numbers, the SAP tables DD002L, DD003L, REPOSRC, and SEOCLASS, which are part of the SAP system and contain important metadata, remain the same in both the source system and the target system. However, another table, AFPO, which contains application-specific data, is truncated: 

Source: Ôøº                                                                         Target: 

When we tested the Shell Copy scenario on our own small production system, we saw a significant drop in the volume size of the database: 

 Source:                                                                                                         Target: 

 

We expect that the reduction ratio will vary a lot based on how much application data your SAP system contains. At the time of the blog post, the Shell Copy scenario is only available through the product provisioning functionality for ‚ÄòEHP8 of SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP‚Äô: 

 

The Shell Copy scenario is a homogeneous process, which means it works with the same type of database on both the source and target systems. It supports SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE), Oracle, MS SQL Server, and IBM Db2 for Linux, UNIX and Windows.  

Another key difference from the traditional System Copy is that Shell Copy uses a more advanced migration tool called the Database Migration Option (DMO) in Software Update Manager (SUM) 2.0, instead of the old migration monitor. 

Thanks to the features of SUM DMO, the Shell Copy process is not only more efficient, but also reduces the overall downtime. For example, the export takes place online with a manageable number of R3load jobs, so you don‚Äôt have to shut down the running SAP system during the Shell Copy process.  To ensure smooth operation of the productive processes, we recommend that you schedule the export in times of reduced workload.

entry.title: Re: Why can't MIRO provisional invoice conditions be edited?
entry.content:
Why Conditions are greyed out in MIRO is because, Provisional/Differential Invoice (Type '8') is designed for adjustments, not for altering pricing logic. SAP restricts condition editing here to maintain consistency with the original PO and GR. 3rd Party Spot Purchase Orders often lack GR-based invoice verification, which limits flexibility in MIRO. Conditions are copied from the PO and locked for editing to prevent discrepancies between PO and invoice values.

Some workarounds are

If business process allows, use standard invoice type (1) instead of provisional (8). This may allow condition editing depending on PO setup.

You can implement custom logic to enable condition editing by enhancing the MIRO screen behavior. This requires ABAP development and careful testing to avoid inconsistencies.

Ensure that the PO type allows for invoice verification with editable conditions. Some custom PO types may have restrictions hardcoded or via user exits.
